Award.AwardTitle: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Fundamental Study of Impacts of Manufacturing Processes and Automation on Material Properties of Composite Products

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Fiber reinforced polymer composites, by virtue of their high stiffness and high strength-to-weight ratio, are increasingly used in a wide range of industries such as transportation, marine, wind energy, aerospace, and construction. Automation of composite laminates manufacturing is instrumental in meeting the growing demand for composites and promises to revolutionize composite-dependent industries. However, the few existing layup automation systems are prohibitively expensive and are not fully optimized for product quality. This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) research aims to establish a systematic framework that will assist in solving the critical challenges in automation, monitoring and control for composite laminates manufacturing. The framework will establish the necessary fundamental understanding of relationships among composite constituents' properties, principal composite manufacturing processes and automation, and fabricated product quality. The new knowledge will help increase productivity and quality of composite laminates manufacturing. Results from this research will assist U.S. composite manufacturers and benefit the U.S. economy and society. This GOALI research employs a multi-disciplinary approach (involving solid mechanics, composites engineering, control theory and robotics) to achieve the research objectives. In addition, it incorporates research goals with industrial needs and helps broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in research and enhance engineering education.

This research will fill the knowledge gap in the complex interactions between fabrication parameters and laminas' temperature- and time- dependent properties (viscoelasticity and tackiness) and their impact on the properties of composite laminates (i.e., a stack of multi-directional laminas arranged to exhibit specific mechanical properties). The research team will (1) create multi-physics manufacturing process models to predict impacts of process parameters on manufacturing induced defects and final product quality, and conduct experiments to verify the models; (2) gain an understanding on the roles of quality inspection and optimal control in increasing productivity through manufacturing dynamics simulations; and (3) obtain the knowledge on how to control the physical process to ensure the product quality as a guideline for manufacturing practices.

Institution.Name: SUNY Institute of Technology Utica-Rome
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
The composites manufacturing industry has been growing steadily. However, the majority of composites manufacturers (small to medium businesses) are still using labor-intensive hand layup operations, which are constrained by the operator's skill and consistency, and often result in high layup errors, material wastage and low productivity. The existing automated solutions mainly include Automated Tape Laying (ATL) and Automated Fiber Placement (AFP). Though those machines have the integrated capability of unrolling, cutting, and laying the prepreg tape, they often involve large-scale machinery, and are heavy investments for small to medium-sized composites manufacturers and only suitable for massive production. This project aimed at exploring a cost-effective automated composite layup solution which would offer competent manufacturing quality, adaptability and productivity for prepreg-based composite manufacturing in small to medium-sized composites manufacturers. A robotic prepreg layup process was proposed and researched.

An experimental system for the proposed robotic prepreg layup process was created. It was designed and built based on a dual-arm robot. Vacuum cup grippers were adopted and enhanced for picking and placing prepreg composite plies. A rolling end-effector was designed and fabricated for laying prepreg plies. Different robotic operations were achieved by switching in different end-effectors. A force and torque sensor was integrated to the rolling end-effector for providing the feedback of the contact force during the robotic prepreg layup process. Robot programs were developed for robot sensing and operations. A practical and quick path planning approach was used to improve the efficiency and reduce the complexity of robot path planning, based on waypoint sampling and interpolation and with a consideration of the contact force. The general flow of the robotic prepreg layup process was programmed and realized using the experimental system, which validated the concept of the robotic prepreg layup process.

An innovative prepreg tape supplier for composite manufacturing processes was designed, and a prototype device was created. The resulting tape supplier can cut and supply composite prepreg tapes and remove the backing paper. It is compact in size and convenient to install and use. This solution facilitates the usage of a compact pick-and-place type of robot to carry out the tape laying process. It contributes to the justification of the overall robotic composite manufacturing scheme, and makes the proposed robotic composite prepreg layup system a complete and self-contained manufacturing system. Moreover, the tape supplier will also provide a consistent and quick tape delivery solution for the manual composite layup process.

The resulting robotic prepreg layup process and system is more compact and economic than the existing heavy machinery of ATL and AFP. It is suitable for small and medium composites manufacturers and for flexible and small batch composite manufacturing and repair operations. The automated solution researched by this project would potentially benefit the composites manufacturing industry at large, especially small to medium-sized composites manufacturing businesses.

Moreover, this project contributed to education by providing training and practice opportunities to a number of students at both undergraduate and graduate levels in both Mechanical Engineering and Computer Science majors. It motivated those students to learn and seek new knowledge and solutions, and helped them gain the understanding of life-long learning. In addition, the robotic experimental system acquired and developed in this project will provide a significant experimental platform for a broader range of research and education activities in robotics.

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2019
Modified by: Yu Zhou
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The composites manufacturing industry has been growing steadily. However, the majority of composites manufacturers (small to medium businesses) are still using labor-intensive hand layup operations, which are constrained by the operator's skill and consistency, and often result in high layup errors, material wastage and low productivity. The existing automated solutions mainly include Automated Tape Laying (ATL) and Automated Fiber Placement (AFP). Though those machines have the integrated capability of unrolling, cutting, and laying the prepreg tape, they often involve large-scale machinery, and are heavy investments for small to medium-sized composites manufacturers and only suitable for massive production. This project aimed at exploring a cost-effective automated composite layup solution which would offer competent manufacturing quality, adaptability and productivity for prepreg-based composite manufacturing in small to medium-sized composites manufacturers. A robotic prepreg layup process was proposed and researched. An experimental system for the proposed robotic prepreg layup process was created. It was designed and built based on a dual-arm robot. Vacuum cup grippers were adopted and enhanced for picking and placing prepreg composite plies. A rolling end-effector was designed and fabricated for laying prepreg plies. The general flow of the robotic prepreg layup process was programmed and realized using the experimental system, which validated the concept of the robotic prepreg layup process. The resulting tape supplier can cut and supply composite prepreg tapes and remove the backing paper. It is compact in size and convenient to install and use. It contributes to the justification of the overall robotic composite manufacturing scheme, and makes the proposed robotic composite prepreg layup system a complete and self-contained manufacturing system. Moreover, the tape supplier will also provide a consistent and quick tape delivery solution for the manual composite layup process. The resulting robotic prepreg layup process and system is more compact and economic than the existing heavy machinery of ATL and AFP. It is suitable for small and medium composites manufacturers and for flexible and small batch composite manufacturing and repair operations. The automated solution researched by this project would potentially benefit the composites manufacturing industry at large, especially small to medium-sized composites manufacturing businesses. Moreover, this project contributed to education by providing training and practice opportunities to a number of students at both undergraduate and graduate levels in both Mechanical Engineering and Computer Science majors. It motivated those students to learn and seek new knowledge and solutions, and helped them gain the understanding of life-long learning. In addition, the robotic experimental system acquired and developed in this project will provide a significant experimental platform for a broader range of research and education activities in robotics.
